info.title: Team Manager API
info.description:
# Introduction

Welcome to the D4H Team Manager REST API, a RESTful API that allows you to access Team Manager data and services. Our API is designed to enable seamless integration with your own applications, websites, and other tools.

With the REST API, you can perform most of the activities available from the Team Manager application, such as managing personel, equipment, exercises, updating their data, etc.

**Notice: the D4H Team Manager REST API is not yet feature complete, future updates will increase functionality but please let us know if something you need is missing and we can try to prioritise it**

## Getting Authenticated

D4H Team Manager's API uses token-based authentication. There are two types of tokens:

- **Personal Access Tokens**. These are used when developing an integration for yourself or for your organization. They have the convenience of being long-lived tokens, and they can be easily generated from the Unified Accounts web UI. Personal Access Tokens should only be used in applications that don't require the ability to authenticate multiple users. If your application needs to be able to support multiple users, then your application should use OAuth to obtain Standard UA Tokens.
- **Standard UA Access Tokens**. These tokens are issued by D4H Unified Accounts after a successful user login. By implementing an OAuth-compatible login "dance", your application can enable its users to log in using their credentials and securely obtain an Access Token which then can be used to invoke the D4H API. Please contact our [help desk](mailto:help@d4h.com) if you are planning to build an application that falls under this category.

All token types are accepted by the REST API and should be provided in the HTTP request Authorization header:

```text
Authorization: Bearer <token>
```

### Generating a Personal Access Token

Your account must be migrated to Unified Accounts authentication to be able to use the Personal Access Tokens. Also, your Team or Organisation must enable Personal Access Tokens in their settings under _API Access_.

These can be created under _Manage Personal Access Tokens_:

![The "Manage Tokens" Page in D4H Unified Accounts](public/docs/screenshot-my-account.jpg)

1. In the page you can manage existing tokens or create a new one under the “Create Token” link.

2. Make sure “Team Manager” is checked under the “Products access” section so you’re able to use these tokens in the D4H Team Manager REST API.

Finally, after pressing “Next”, the token will be displayed. The token is not saved by D4H, so lost tokens are not recoverable.

The JWT token should then be used on the HTTP Request Authorization headers.

Please contact D4H support if you have any problems accessing or activating your Unified Account.

## Making Requests

If you are completely unfamiliar with making REST API requests, a good first step would be trying
some simple requests using a terminal / command-line application called `curl`. This is installed by
default on newer MacOs and Windows versions, but can be installed manually on older ones.

### Your First Request

After getting an access token of some kind, open your terminal / command line and try the following command (after
modifying it to replace `YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN` with your token):

```bash
curl -X GET -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" -o d4h-api-whoami-response.json https://api.team-manager.us.d4h.com/v3/whoami
```

This will make a `GET` request to the `whoami` endpoint, which if successful will return a JSON
response similar to that shown [here](#tag/Accounts-Credentials/paths/~1v3~1whoami/get). This will
be stored in `d4h-api-whoami-response.json` in the directory from which the command is run.

### Request Contexts

Within the `whoami` response, you will find arrays of `members` and `officers` objects. Each of
these essentially represents a team-membership or organisation-officership which your token allows requests to be performed as.

Each member or officer object will have an `owner` object within, this being a representation the team or organisation itself. Each `owner` will have an `id`, and this is their _context-identifier_.

Here is a part of an example response from `whoami`

```json
{
  "members": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "owner": 
      {
        "resourceType": "Team",
        "id": 600,
        "title": "Team Y",
      },
      "name": "Member X",
      "hasAccess": true,
      "resourceType": "Member",
    },
  ]
}
```

In the Team Manager API most requests are made within a specific _context_, this can be thought of
the point-of-view from which a request is made. A request's context is included in the URL.
Based on the above example, the _context_ is `team` and the _context-identifier_  is `600`. Hence, an example request
url would be `https://api.team-manager.us.d4h.com/v3/team/600/whiteboard`.

The two contexts that would apply for most
users are `team` and `organisation`, and these would be followed in the URL by the id of the team or
organisation.

See the [General URL Structure](#section/Introduction/General-URL-Structure) for further information on contexts and what each part of the URL means.

### Creating Data

The following command is slightly more complex:

```bash
curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" -d "{ \"text\": \"I wrote this via the API\", \"important\": true }" -o d4h-api-post-response.json https://api.team-manager.us.d4h.com/v3/YOUR_CONTEXT/YOUR_CONTEXT_ID_FROM_WHOAMI/whiteboard
```

It will make a `POST` type request, which is usually used for the _creation_ of data. It will use the JSON
you provide via the `-d` flag in the command. The API will take whatever is after `-d` and try to
use it to create a resource. Your ability to create resources will be determined by your
permissions, which are viewable in the data returned from the `whoami` request.

This command should create a whiteboard note (if you have that module turned on), that is marked as
important and has the text contained in the JSON.

### Alternative API clients

If you are not comfortable with the command line, or just want making requests to be more
convenient, there are many (many) varied GUI-based REST API clients. Some examples at
the time of writing:

- [Bruno](https://docs.usebruno.com/)
- [Httpie](https://httpie.io/desktop)
- [Insomnia](https://insomnia.rest/)
- [Postman](https://www.postman.com/)

## General URL Structure

Consider the following example URL template:

```text
[verb] https://api.team-manager.us.d4h.com/[version]/[context]/[context-identifier]/[resource]/[resource-identifier]?[query-params]
```

An example would be:

```text
GET https://api.team-manager.us.d4h.com/v3/team/1/incidents/234?size=100&search=angry%20clown
```

As a general rule, looking to the verb, the URL should indicate what the API endpoint does.

- `version` should be increased on breaking changes
- `context` represents the context the request is being made under, currently only `team` or `organisations`
  - `context-identifier` represents an unique identifier for the context
- `resource` represents the entity domain relative to the context
  - `resource-identifier` represents an unique identifier for the resource
- `query-params` represent contextual data attributes that don't change the resource domain.
  - They can be used for:
    - search
    - pagination / ordering / sorting
    - a team-context request wishing to include/exclude organisation-context resources from results
    - etc...

### Contexts

Contexts are not a resource, but a point-of-view from which a request is made. There is an implicit `team`-`organisation` relationship that is not obvious from the url, but should be borne in mind. A `team` generally has access to its own data, but also _some_ data of its parent `organisation`. An `organisation` has access to its own data, but also _some_ of its multiple sub-`team`s. The data shared can vary by `resource`-type.

Therefore, the `team` context in a request means: the data owned by this team and that implicitly shared by its associated `organisation` if any.

Correspondingly, the `organisation` context in a request means: the data owned by this organisation and that which is implicitly shared by its associated `team`s.

#### Context-Entity Endpoints

Since `team` and `organisation` are used in the URL structure to designate the context, their plural form can appear again in the same URL to request data about the entities themselves.

- `/v3/team/123/teams/123` - returning data about the team `123`
- `/v3/team/123/teams/456` - returning data about a sibling team `456`
- `/v3/team/123/organisations/789` - returning data about a team's parent organisation
- `/v3/organisation/789/organisations/789` - returning data about the organisation itself
- `/v3/organisation/789/teams/123` - returning data about one of the organisation's child teams

As for any other endpoint, the data returned will be as from the point-of-view specified by the context.

#### Requesting or filtering data from multiple contexts

It may be desirable to retrieve resources from multiple contexts in one request, or exclude data from the
implicit team/organisation relationship. In these cases specific query parameters (`exclude_org_data`, `exclude_teams_data`)
are to be used as modifiers to indicate intent

- `/v3/team/123/equipment-brands` - team-owned and org-owned
- `/v3/team/123/equipment-brands?exclude_org_data=true` - team-owned only
- `/v3/organisation/123/equipment-brands` org-owned and sub-team-owned
- `/v3/organisation/123/equipment-brands?exclude_teams_data=true` org-owned only

These modifiers should be available on every appropriate `GET` route and also apply
to functional `GET` endpoints

"Sibling" teams' data must be requested separately

## Resource Ownership

In responses resource ownership is represented
as an `owner` object which includes the owner id and its resource type.

```json
{
 "owner": {
    "id": 1,
    "resourceType": "Team"
  }
}
```

## Resource / Entity Bundles

"Bundling" varies between resource types. The existing bundles based around string names is deprecated, and the goal is to eventually move all bundles over to resource-bundle endpoint.
But, in the meantime, bundle string properties will be named `deprecatedBundle`, reserving the `bundle` / `resourceBundle` property name for
a resource-bundle object in the future. `deprecated` should be included in both the payload and response keys.

```json
{
  "bundle": {
    "id": 1,
    "resourceType": "ResourceBundle"
  }
}
```

## Member Addresses

The members endpoints currently return and accept a `deprecatedAddress` string to represent a member's address. This is to allow us to add an `address` object in the future
with individual `street`, `postcode`, etc properties without breaking backwards-compatability.

## Enums

Enums are always case-sensitive strings. Specifically:

- Enums in query parameters, payloads, and responses are always in `SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE`.
- Context enums in urls (and urls in general) are always in `kebab-case`.
- Resource type enums anywhere are always in `PascalCase`.

Explanations for their meaning and use should be provided in either the validation description, or in a preface paragraph for the endpoint as a whole

## Validation

Request parameters, queries and payloads will be validated against strict schemas as per the API endpoint reference below. Validation failure will generate meaningful 400 HTTP errors that will include all violations when possible.

Supplying additional keys not defined in an endpoint schema is forbidden and will also result in 400 errors.

### Important Remarks

#### Sanitization

Strings are not to be sanitized beyond what is needed for the API itself. It is up to the client to sanitize api responses for its own uses.

#### Date Format

Dates should be on the wire as ISO 8601 strings (`"1975-08-19T23:15:30.000Z"`). Team Manager stores all date-times as UTC so received
date-times will be saved as that, and responses will be returned as UTC ISO 8601 strings.

#### Value Conversion

The API will do no conversion of values, which will be stored in the lowest precision required using the metric system. This includes currency, which will be stored in the lowest denomination. It's up to clients to use the context's settings to determine how to display each value.

#### Location data

Responses will format location data as per the GeoJSON format for "Point" (see spec [here](https://geojson.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#point))

```json
{
  "location": {
    "type": "Point",
    "coordinates": [0.0, 0.0]
  }
}
```

## Request Limits

If you're requesting **very** frequently, a slowdown will be applied to your requests in a sliding time window.
If the limit is `X` requests per minute, and your request frequency goes over this, an additional
`Y` milliseconds will be added **cumulativly per request** to the response time of each subsequent request until your request rate falls back below `X` per minute.

If your request frequency reaches a further limit, you will receive only an error response with the [429 http status code](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/429).

We reserve the right to adjust the limits, but you should never run into them during normal use. If you have a use case requiring an increased limit, please contact support.

### Response Headers

If your requests are subject to rate limiting each response will have additional headers that conform to [the seventh draft of the IETF rate limit header specification](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpapi-ratelimit-headers-07).

This amounts to the following additional headers:

- `ratelimit-policy`
  - example value: `200;w=300`
  - 200 requests within a 300 second window
- `ratelimit`
  - example value: `limit=200, remaining=199, reset=300`
  - the limit is `200`, you have `199` left in the current timeframe, and it will reset after `300` seconds

These headers refer to limit of requests before you start receiving 429 errors. Request slowdown will happen before these limits are exceeded.

## Error Handling

D4H Team Manager REST API uses a common data contract for returnings error (HTTP 4xx and 5xx) responses - `statusCode` represents the HTTP code. `code` is a machine readable error. `message` is a user focused error message. An optional `data` property contains additional details, for example validation errors.

### Specific Errors

#### HTTP 429

[429 http status code](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/429) - See [Request Limits](#request-limits) for details

tags.name: Custom Fields
tags.description:
Please note, these endpoints are for interacting with Custom Fields themselves, _not_ the values of a custom field for any particular resource.

In order to 'fill-in' a field for a particular resource, you can use the CREATE or UPDATE endpoint for the resource itself -- by populating the `customFieldValues` property in your request payload.

Similarly to view the values of fields for a particular resource, those values will be returned alongside all of the other resource properties from its own endpoint -- again within the `customFieldValues` property.

tags.name: Duties
tags.description:
Duty period creation (`/duties/add-duty-period`) and updating (`/duties/update-duty-period`) endpoints are considered 'functional' endpoints, instead of the typical REST CRUD endpoint. Mainly because they do not behave in the standard manner, and may not even return a resource (however in that case you will receive an empty response but with an appropriate status code to indicate that the request was still a success). Functional endpoints always use POST unless they are purely for data retrieval.

Each member has a 'default duty' state ('ON' or 'OFF') and can have a default role. If your member is 'ON' by default you can create 'OFF' duty resources for them, but an 'ON' resource will only be created if there is some distinction from their defaults - i.e. either a role id that is different to their default, or adding notes. Otherwise, since there is no actual resource for the default duty state of a member - there is nothing to return.

To 'create' an 'ON' period for a user that defaults to 'ON' you would make a POST request - but no actual resource will be created (unless the role or notes are different). The api will split or edit any 'OFF' duty periods in order to fit the 'ON' period in, and return an empty response with an appropriate status code to indicate that nothing was created but the operation was successful.

Similarly, when updating a duty other duties can be affected. They can potentially be deleted, shortened or lengthened, absorb or be absorbed by the target duty resource. The returned duty period, if there is one, may not have the same start or end dates as were sent - depending on what existing duty periods there already were. The target duty period may be deleted if the update would result in it matching the member's defaults.

Deletion of a duty period resource, can be performed as with other resources. Two things to note however:

- Firstly, when a repeating duty is deleted using the standard method - if it is the "parent" duty of the repitition then the next chronological duty by date will become the new "parent" to all other duties.
- Secondly, if query parameter `all_following` is set to true and the duty is a repeating one, then every child duty following the target one will also be deleted.

The creation of repeating duties is not currently supported by the API. Updating is supported, but any changes will be applied to that single duty resource and not any repetitions.

tags.name: Equipment Inspections
tags.description:
### Notes on creation of Inspection Results

Inspection Results are handled a bit differently to other resources. Basically when an inspection is completed, the system itself should automatically create a new 'incomplete' result for that inspection for that item. This might not happen instantly depending on how much equipment / inspections your team has, but would normally be available straight away.

Essentially, you should never have to create a result resource yourself (so long as the inspection is active) - only update the sole incomplete one to be 'complete'. This applies only to Inspection Results, not inspections themselves or inspection steps.

tags.name: Resource Bundles
tags.description: Currently, only custom fields can be added to resource bundles. Each bundle is only for a specific sub-resource-type. Meaning, resource bundles can be used to collect together custom fields for a particular resource type. You can have bundles of member custom fields, bundles of incident custom fields, etc.
